questions.text: A 54-year-old woman with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) was diagnosed with an upper respiratory tract infection, and erythromycin was prescribed. Her COPD was reasonably well controlled on oral theophylline and inhaled albuterol. Which of the following would be an appropriate change in the patient’s therapeutic regimen at this time?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Decrease the dose of theophylline
 Explanation:
• Erythromycin inhibits CYP450 enzymes → ↓ metabolism of theophylline
• Theophylline has a narrow therapeutic index → risk of toxicity (seizures, arrhythmia)
• So, reduce dose of theophylline to avoid toxicity
• No need to increase albuterol or add steroids unless exacerbation worsens

questions.text: Mechanism of action of statins-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Inhibit HMG CoA reductase enzyme
 Explanation:
• Statins (e.g., atorvastatin) inhibit HMG-CoA reductase, the rate-limiting enzyme in cholesterol synthesis
• ↓ Cholesterol → ↑ LDL receptor expression → ↓ serum LDL
• They do not stimulate the enzyme, and HMG-CoA synthase is upstream

questions.text: Morphine and pentazocine both act upon similar receptors in the central nervous system and produce analgesic effect. If pentazocine is given to a morphine addict it may produce withdrawal symptoms. What kind of action does pentazocine have at opioid mu receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A full antagonist action
 Explanation:
• Pentazocine: antagonist at μ, full agonist at κ
• Competes with morphine (full μ-agonist) → displaces it → precipitates withdrawal
• Classic behavior of partial agonists in opioid dependence

questions.text: Which NSAID given as single daily dose
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Piroxicam
 Explanation:
• Piroxicam: long half-life (45–50 hours) → once daily dosing
• Others:
o Ketorolac: QID
o Diclofenac: BID
o Naproxen: BID

questions.text: Drug given via this route is/are:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

BCG
 Explanation:
• Insulin: subcutaneous
• BCG: intradermal (forearm)
• MMR: subcutaneous
• So all are administered via parenteral non-IV routes

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman has been admitted to the coronary care unit with acute myocardial infarction. She develops acute severe heart failure with marked pulmonary edema. Which one of the following drugs would be most useful to improve pumping action in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Dobutamine
 Explanation:
• Dobutamine: β₁-agonist → ↑ cardiac contractility
• Useful in acute decompensated heart failure
• Others:
o Digoxin: slow onset, used in chronic HF
o Furosemide: relieves symptoms but doesn't improve contractility
o Nitrates: reduce preload, not inotropes

questions.text: A patient having weakness in the limb muscles and it is more in the evening time after work exertion. Edrophonium was used for diagnosis. Condition of the patient improving after giving edrophonium. This patient is likely to be suffering from:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Myasthenia gravis
 Explanation:
• Myasthenia gravis:
o Autoantibodies against ACh receptors
o Fluctuating weakness, especially in evening
o Edrophonium test (Tensilon test): transient improvement → diagnostic
• LEMS improves with activity
• Cholinergic crisis worsens with edrophonium

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman complains of chest pain following any sustained exercise. She is diagnosed with atherosclerotic angina. She is prescribed sublingual nitroglycerin for treatment of acute chest pain. Which of the following adverse effects of sublingual nitroglycerin can be prevented by atenolol?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Reflex tachycardia
 Explanation:
• Nitroglycerin → vasodilation → hypotension → reflex sympathetic activation → tachycardia
• Atenolol: β₁-blocker → suppresses this reflex
• Headache = direct vasodilation
• Methemoglobinemia = rare idiosyncratic

questions.text: A patient on bipolar disorder treatment developed hypertension. He was started on thiazides for hypertension. After few days, he developed coarse tremors, confusion and weakness of limbs. Which drug toxicity occurred?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Lithium
 Explanation:
• Lithium toxicity precipitated by thiazides
o Thiazides ↓ Na⁺ reabsorption → ↑ proximal lithium reabsorption
• Symptoms: tremor, ataxia, confusion, muscle weakness
• Monitor lithium levels when starting thiazide

questions.text: A 56-year-old male is having G6PD deficiency. He develops Plasmodium vivax malaria and treated for the same. Now he complains of severe fatigue, back pain, and darkened urine. Which one of the following anti-malarial drugs used in treatment could have caused his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Primaquine
 Explanation:
• Primaquine causes oxidative stress → hemolysis in G6PD deficiency
• Used for radical cure of P. vivax/ovale (kills liver hypnozoites)
• Always test G6PD before prescribing primaquine

questions.text: Which of the following antihypertensive medications would be preferred for the treatment of chronic hypertension in a 33-year-old pregnant woman?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Methyldopa
 Explanation:
• Methyldopa is first-line for chronic hypertension in pregnancy
o Central α2 agonist → ↓ sympathetic tone
• Clonidine: also α2 agonist but not preferred due to rebound hypertension
• Atenolol: can cause fetal growth retardation
• Carvedilol: β + α1 blocker → not recommended in pregnancy

questions.text: A female developed pain and insect crawling like sensation on legs at night which is relieved by shaking her legs. Which of the following is drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Gabapentin
 Explanation:
• Classic features of Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS)
• Pramipexole: dopamine agonist
• Gabapentin: best if pain predominant
• Vit B12 & iron if deficiency confirmed, but not DOC

questions.text: Patient treated with fluphenazine presents the following day with a unilateral stiff, sore neck and back; What was the neurological reaction--which drug treatments might be appropriate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Acute dystonia: Diphenhydramine
 Explanation:
• Fluphenazine (typical antipsychotic) → EPS like acute dystonia
• Diphenhydramine or benztropine are first-line for reversal
• L-DOPA & bromocriptine are not used in this context
• Tardive dyskinesia occurs later, not acutely

questions.text: A talented 21­ year ­old violinist’s musical career is in trouble because he becomes acutely anxious, suffering from tremors and palpitations, whenever he is asked to play in front of an audience. What medication can help him in reducing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Propranolol
 Explanation:
• Performance anxiety (situational) is treated with β-blockers
o Propranolol: controls physical symptoms (tremor, palpitations)
• Clonazepam: for general anxiety
• Escitalopram: takes weeks to act
• Risperidone: antipsychotic, not appropriate here

choices.text: Amount of the drug reaching to systemic circulation in unchanged form
Drug metabolized in liver after reaching the systemic circulation
Drug metabolized in liver before reaches the systemic circulation

questions.text: Bioavailability: True is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Amount of the drug reaching systemic circulation in unchanged form
 Explanation:
• Bioavailability = % of drug that reaches systemic circulation unchanged
• Oral drugs → undergo first-pass metabolism (before systemic circulation)
• Rectal route partially bypasses liver but is not maximal for all drugs

questions.text: Which of the following medications would be preferred as monotherapy for the treatment of a 53-year-old man with moderate hypertension and mild benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Terazosin
 Explanation:
• Terazosin: α1-blocker → treats both HTN and BPH
• Tamsulosin is selective for prostate, not for BP
• Carvedilol and propranolol: not first-line in BPH

questions.text: A 43 year old woman who presents with a 2 week history of epigastric pain and a positive serum antibody for H. pylori. Which of the following would be considered the preferred initial therapy for H. pylori?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

PPI + Amoxicillin + Clarithromycin
 Explanation:
• Standard triple therapy:
o PPI + Amoxicillin + Clarithromycin
• Quadruple therapy includes bismuth, used in resistance
• Levofloxacin used in second-line regimens

questions.text: Which of the following drug used in congestive heart failure patients to decrease mortality by inhibiting remodelling of left ventricle when used for long term purpose:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

All of the above
 Explanation:
• All 3 options have mortality benefits:
o Spironolactone (aldosterone antagonist)
o Hydralazine + nitrates (esp. in African Americans)
o Sacubitril + Valsartan: ARNI combo → ↓ remodeling, ↓ mortality

questions.text: Schedule X drugs are all except-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Thalidomide
 Explanation:
• Schedule X: high abuse potential + prescription control
o Includes morphine, phenobarbitone, amphetamines
• Thalidomide is Schedule H, not X

choices.text: Sumatriptan action is agonistically 5 -HT 1B/1D receptor mediated

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding 5 -HT derivatives:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Sumatriptan action is agonistically 5-HT1B/1D receptor mediated
 Explanation:
• Sumatriptan: 5-HT₁B/₁D agonist → causes vasoconstriction of cranial vessels
• Ondansetron is a 5-HT3 antagonist, not agonist
• Cisapride is a 5-HT4 agonist
• Cyproheptadine is a 5-HT2 antagonist, not agonist

questions.text: Which of the following antihypertensive agents would decrease renin release?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Metoprolol
 Explanation:
• Metoprolol: β1-selective blocker → inhibits sympathetic stimulation of juxtaglomerular cells → ↓ renin release
• Prazosin (α1-blocker): vasodilator, no direct renin effect
• Captopril: ACE inhibitor, blocks angiotensin II but increases renin due to feedback
• Nitroprusside: direct vasodilator, no renin effect

choices.text: Agranulocytosis or aplastic anemia, requiring stopping both drugs immediately
Breakthrough seizures from increased phenytoin clearance
Thromboembolism from the estrogen component of the contraceptive

questions.text: A woman who has been taking an oral contraceptive for several years is diagnosed with epilepsy and started phenytoin. What is the most likely consequence of adding phenytoin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Reduced contraceptive efficacy
 Explanation:
• Phenytoin: potent CYP450 inducer → increases metabolism of estrogen/progestins
o Leads to contraceptive failure
• Agranulocytosis is rare; seizures wouldn’t worsen
• Thromboembolism is an estrogen risk but unrelated to phenytoin

questions.text: A 56­ year­ old man presents to his primary care physician complaining of difficulty urinating. Digital rectal exam reveals an enlarged prostate. The patient is started on terazosin, after which his symptoms improve dramatically. Which of the following side effects he is most likely to experience?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Dizziness
 Explanation:
• Terazosin: α1-blocker → vasodilation → first-dose orthostatic hypotension → dizziness
• Headache, diarrhea, flatulence are less common
• Warn patient to take at bedtime to reduce fall risk

choices.text: Rapid cycling bipolar disorder and Valproate

questions.text: Patient presented with 6 episodes of depression, mania & hypomania in last 1 year with recovery phase in between. What is the probable diagnosis and drug used is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Rapid cycling bipolar disorder and Valproate
 Explanation:
• Rapid cycling: ≥4 mood episodes/year
• Valproate: mood stabilizer of choice in this scenario
• Lithium works better in classic bipolar I
• Carbamazepine is alternative, especially in mixed states

questions.text: Which combination of seizures and it’s first line treatment drug is false:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Myoclonic seizures: Topiramate
 Explanation:
• Topiramate is not first-line for myoclonic seizures
o Valproate is DOC
• Correct pairs:
o Absence → Ethosuximide
o Focal → Levetiracetam
o Generalized → Valproate

questions.text: A patient with acute chest pain was given Nitroglycerine via sublingual route. Chest pain was relieved within few minutes. What is the mechanism for causing vasodilation by Nitrates:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Release of nitric oxide
 Explanation:
• Nitrates release NO → activates guanylate cyclase → ↑ cGMP → smooth muscle relaxation
• Not via PDE inhibition (sildenafil does that)
• Endothelin = vasoconstrictor
• Calcium channel blockers work differently

questions.text: A patient presented with breathlessness, pitting edema. He has heart disease also. Which of the following is drug is to be given in this patient:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Na-K-2Cl transport inhibitor in TAL
 Explanation:
• This refers to loop diuretics (e.g., furosemide)
o Inhibit Na-K-2Cl in thick ascending limb
o Rapid and powerful diuresis in CHF
• Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors = weak diuretics
• DCT inhibitors (thiazides) less potent
• Aldosterone blockers used as adjuncts

questions.text: An elderly patient is diagnosed with Alzheimer’s disease due to his symptoms of dementia. Which neurotransmitter is important for causing these symptoms:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Acetylcholine
 Explanation:
• AD features cholinergic neuron degeneration
o ↓ ACh in cortex and hippocampus
• Hence, treatment: AChE inhibitors (e.g., donepezil)
• Dopamine = Parkinsonism
• Serotonin = depression
• NE = attention, mood

questions.text: A pregnant lady was given indomethacin in last trimester. It could lead to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Premature closure of ductus arteriosus
 Explanation:
• NSAIDs (like indomethacin) inhibit PGE₂ synthesis
o Can cause premature closure of DA → fetal pulmonary hypertension
• That’s why NSAIDs are contraindicated in 3rd trimester
• PDA closure is intentional postnatally using NSAIDs

questions.text: A young male giving H/O excessive blinking of one eye since last 5 – 6 years. He is not able to control this and when he tried to control frequency increases. This is affecting his professional life decreasing his confidence level. What is the best drug for this patient
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

choices.text: Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration
Rate of elimination is dependent on plasma concentration
Clearance of drug is always constant

questions.text: True about zero order kinetics-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration
 Explanation:
• In zero-order kinetics, a constant amount (not fraction) of drug is eliminated per unit time
o Enzymes are saturated
o Seen with: Phenytoin, Ethanol, Aspirin (high doses)
• Half-life and clearance are not constant

questions.text: A 72 year old man with a documented NSAID­ induced ulcer and is H.pylori negative. He must continue the NSAID for osteoarthritis. Which of the following is the specific medication for ulcer healing and prevention of future ulcers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Misoprostol
 Explanation:
• Misoprostol: PGE1 analogue → promotes mucus/bicarbonate → protects gastric mucosa
o Best option when NSAIDs can't be stopped and H. pylori is negative
• PPIs (pantoprazole) also help but misoprostol is specifically cytoprotective
• Sucralfate coats ulcer but not effective for NSAID-related protection

questions.text: A female presented with pain and redness in her great toe. Serum uric acid level was 9.7 mg/dl. Apart from analgesic, one more drug was prescribed to her that decreases the formation of uric acid. Which enzyme is likely to be inhibited by this drug:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Xanthine oxidase
 Explanation:
• Drug = Allopurinol or Febuxostat → inhibit xanthine oxidase
o ↓ uric acid formation from hypoxanthine/xanthine
• Others:
o DHFR: target of methotrexate
o Thymidylate synthase: inhibited by 5-FU
o PRPP transferase: involved in purine synthesis, not target here

questions.text: A patient of pancreatic carcinoma (clinical case was given). You gave morphine for relieving pain. After few days, the pain is not relieved as relieved earlier. Why?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Desensitization of opioid receptor
 Explanation:
• Tolerance occurs with chronic opioid use
o Due to receptor desensitization or downregulation
• Not due to upregulation or decreased absorption
• Management: opioid rotation or adjuvants

questions.text: One drug addict person presented with ulceration over skin. This patient also having itching and scratch marks over skin. He is having tachycardia, hypertensin and mydriasis. Which substance is causing these symptoms:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cocaine
 Explanation:
• Cocaine: sympathomimetic → mydriasis, HTN, tachycardia
o Vasoconstriction → skin necrosis/ulcers
o Itching & scratching = formication
• Heroin → miosis
• LSD → hallucinations
• Cannabis → sedation, not stimulatory

choices.text: Domperidone block levodopa induced vomiting & it’s therapeutic potential

questions.text: All of the following statements are true in levodopa treatment in parkinsonism except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Domperidone blocks levodopa-induced vomiting & its therapeutic potential
 Explanation:
• Domperidone blocks peripheral D2 receptors → ↓ nausea without crossing BBB
o Does NOT block CNS effects of levodopa
• Pyridoxine ↑ peripheral metabolism of levodopa
• Phenothiazines (e.g., chlorpromazine) block D2 → reduce efficacy

questions.text: Patient with vomiting was treated with antiemetics. Patient was relieved of symptoms, but develops abnormal movements and posture. What is the drug to be prescribed to counter the movements?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Benzhexol
 Explanation:
• Likely culprit: metoclopramide or prochlorperazine (D2 antagonists)
o Can cause acute dystonia
• Benzhexol = trihexyphenidyl → central anticholinergic → DOC
• Hyoscine: peripheral antimuscarinic
• Cyproheptadine = 5-HT2/H1 blocker (not for dystonia)

questions.text: A patient is on treatment of acute migraine attack. Now he developed numbness & tingling at the tip of fingers. Which drug is responsible for this and drug used for treatment of this condition is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ergotamine and Sodium nitroprusside
 Explanation:
• Ergotamine: vasoconstrictor → can cause digital ischemia
o Tingling, numbness = vasospasm
• Sodium nitroprusside: vasodilator → used to reverse this
• Sumatriptan can cause similar effects but less severe
• Propranolol not used in acute attacks

questions.text: A child was brought to the emergency department after eating an unknown plant. Skin was dry, high body temperature, pupils were dilated and raised heart rate. Which of the following poisoning occurred to this child:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Dhatura
 Explanation:
• Dhatura poisoning (anticholinergic toxidrome):
o Hot as a hare, dry as a bone, red as a beet, blind as a bat, mad as a hatter
o Dry skin, hyperthermia, mydriasis, hallucinations
• Antidote: Physostigmine
• Poppy: opioids → miosis
• Mushroom: can cause cholinergic or hepatotoxic symptoms
• Cannabinoids: sedation, not this picture

choices.text: Drug C is less potent and more efficacious than drug A
Drug B is less potent and equally efficacious than drug D
Drug D is more potent and more efficacious than drug B
Drug A is more potent and equally efficacious than drug B

questions.text: True statement is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Drug A is more potent and equally efficacious than drug B
 Explanation:
• Potency: lower dose = more potent
• Efficacy: higher maximal effect = more efficacious
• If Drug A reaches same height (efficacy) at a lower dose (leftward), it's more potent and equally efficacious

choices.text: Decreased permeability of the vascular endothelium
Changing the pH of the solution

questions.text: Adding adrenaline to a lidocaine solution to be administered by subcutaneous injection can prolong the duration of local anesthesia by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Local Vasoconstriction
Explanation:
• Adrenaline (epinephrine) causes vasoconstriction at the site of injection.
• This reduces blood flow → delays absorption of lidocaine into systemic circulation → prolongs its local action.
• Also reduces bleeding and systemic toxicity.

questions.text: Patient having c/o pain on face which aggravates on smiling and while touching face. What drug to prescribe to this patient:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Carbamazepine
Explanation:
• Classic presentation of trigeminal neuralgia.
• Carbamazepine is the first-line drug; it's a sodium channel blocker that reduces neuronal firing.
• NSAIDs are ineffective; Levetiracetam is used for seizures, not neuralgia.

questions.text: A farmer presented to emergency with garlic odour breathing, pin point pupil and excessive salivary secretion. Drug of choice to treat this condition is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Atropine
Explanation:
• Suggests organophosphate poisoning (cholinergic crisis).
• Atropine is a muscarinic antagonist → blocks excessive cholinergic activity.
• Pralidoxime is also used, but Atropine is DOC for symptomatic relief.

choices.text: Tab alprazolam 500mcg at bedtime For 7 days
Tab alprazolam 0.5mg at bedtime for 7 days

questions.text: By "Indian medical practioner" best way of prescription of alprazolam is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tab alprazolam 0.5 mg at bedtime for 7 days
Explanation:
• Doses should be written in mg not fractions (avoid “½ mg”).
• Clearly written instructions with dose, frequency, and duration are legally and medically correct.

choices.text: Atropine can be used as antidote
Sodium bicarbonate given to treat acidosis

questions.text: A patient brought to the causality with overdose of amitryptalline. What is not true
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Atropine can be used as antidote
Explanation:
• Amitriptyline overdose causes anticholinergic toxicity (tachycardia, dry mouth, coma).
• Atropine would worsen symptoms.
• Correct treatments include sodium bicarbonate for cardiac toxicity and diazepam for seizures.

questions.text: One pregnant lady on lithium therapy came for antenatal visit in OPD. What is the risk the exposed fetus is having by this drug:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ebstein’s anomaly
Explanation:
• Lithium is teratogenic, especially during the first trimester.
• It causes Ebstein’s anomaly – downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle (a rare congenital heart defect).
• Not associated with neural tube defects or Down syndrome.

questions.text: A 52 year patient came to emergency with severe chest pain. His blood pressure was 150/90 mmHg and diagnosed with chronic angina pectoris. The first line drug for treatment of hypertension in this patient is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Atenolol
Explanation:
• Beta-blockers (e.g., Atenolol) are preferred in patients with both hypertension and stable angina.
• They reduce myocardial oxygen demand by lowering heart rate and contractility.
• Amlodipine and diuretics are useful, but not first-line in angina.

questions.text: Which antidepressant acts via inhibiting the reuptake of both serotonin and norepinephrine:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Venlafaxine
Explanation:
• Venlafaxine is an SNRI (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor).
• Effective in major depressive disorder, anxiety, and neuropathic pain.
• Fluoxetine is SSRI; Amitriptyline is TCA; Phenelzine is MAOI.

questions.text: Disulfiram reaction occurs in alcoholics due to inhibition of which enzyme
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Aldehyde dehydrogenase
Explanation:
• Disulfiram inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase → leads to accumulation of acetaldehyde after alcohol intake.
• This causes unpleasant symptoms: flushing, vomiting, palpitations → discourages drinking.
• Not related to alcohol dehydrogenase.

questions.text: All are true statements except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

PGF2α analogue (Carboprost) – 1st trimester MTP
Explanation:
• Misoprostol (PGE1) → used in 1st trimester MTP.
• Dinoprostone (PGE2) → 2nd trimester MTP.
• Carboprost (PGF2α) → used for postpartum hemorrhage, not 1st trimester abortion.
• So this statement is incorrect.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman suffering from asthma was brought to the emergency department because of a sudden onset of left- side paralysis. Imaging studies confirmed the diagnosis of thromboembolic stroke, and the patient started a treatment that included a drug that acts by blocking platelet P2Y12 receptors. Which of the following drugs has this mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Clopidogrel
Explanation:
• Clopidogrel inhibits P2Y12 ADP receptors on platelets → prevents aggregation.
• Used in stroke, ACS, post-stent, etc.
• Warfarin is a vitamin K antagonist; Alteplase is a thrombolytic; Aminocaproic acid is an antifibrinolytic.

questions.text: After bee sting, A lady developed hypotension and difficulty in breathing. Drug used in this condition is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Adrenaline
Explanation:
• Anaphylaxis → immediate IM adrenaline 1:1000 is first-line.
• It counters bronchospasm (β₂), vasodilation (α₁), and hypotension.
• Other options are secondary or adjunctive.

questions.text: A young male patient was suffering from AML so Doxorubicin based regimen chemotherapy given for treated. After some time he is having swelling in lower limb and breathlessness on excretion & during night time. Which is the possible toxicity to this patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Dilated cardiomyopathy
Explanation:
• Doxorubicin (an anthracycline) is notorious for dose-dependent cardiotoxicity, especially dilated cardiomyopathy.
• Monitor with echocardiogram; limit cumulative dose.

questions.text: Advantages of controlled release drug delivery system are all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lower cost
Explanation:
• Controlled-release systems provide longer duration, fewer doses, and better compliance, but are usually more expensive than conventional formulations.

questions.text: A patient of severe hypertension attended the causality. Drug started without looking for underlying cause of pheochromocytoma. After that patient blood pressure has gone up again. Which drug was most probably prescribed to this patient.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Propranolol
Explanation:
• Propranolol (non-selective β-blocker) can worsen pheochromocytoma by unopposed α-vasoconstriction → hypertensive crisis.
• Always give α-blocker (like phenoxybenzamine) first if pheochromocytoma is suspected.

questions.text: A female patient was on warfarin therapy for prosthetic valves. What advice should be given to her regarding use of this drug during early pregnancy:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Change to heparin
Explanation:
• Warfarin is teratogenic, especially during 6–12 weeks gestation (organogenesis).
• It causes fetal warfarin syndrome (nasal hypoplasia, stippled epiphyses).
• Heparin is safer in pregnancy as it does not cross placenta.

choices.text: D1 receptor, increases renal blood flow

questions.text: Dopamine in low doses acts on which receptor and causes which action:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

D1 receptor, increases renal blood flow
Explanation:
• Low-dose dopamine stimulates D1 receptors → vasodilation in renal, mesenteric, and coronary beds → increases renal perfusion.
• Higher doses → β₁ effect (increased contractility), then α₁ (vasoconstriction).

choices.text: Carbamazepine increase metabolism of other drugs

questions.text: All are true about anticonvulsants except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Valproate stimulates GABA transaminase enzyme
Explanation:
• False statement – Valproate inhibits GABA transaminase (increases GABA levels).
• Phenytoin → gingival hyperplasia.
• Carbamazepine → CYP inducer (↑ metabolism of other drugs).
• Valproate → used in absence, generalized seizures.

questions.text: Which of the following non – BZD sedative drug acting on BZD recdeptor but not having muscle relaxant property is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Zaleplon
Explanation:
• Zaleplon is a “Z-drug” (like zolpidem) → acts on BZ1 subtype of GABA-A receptor.
• Used for sleep-onset insomnia.
• No muscle relaxant, anticonvulsant, or anxiolytic activity.

questions.text: Drug of choice for treatment of malaria due to P. vivax in a pregnant female is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Chloroquine
Explanation:
• Chloroquine is safe in pregnancy.
• Primaquine is contraindicated (risk of hemolysis in G6PD deficiency and unknown fetal G6PD status).
• ACT and Quinine are reserved for resistant/severe cases or P. falciparum.

questions.text: A patient presented after road traffic accident. This patient is having raised ICP but no intracranial hematoma was seen. Which is the best drug to start in this patient to manage his condition:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Mannitol
Explanation:
• Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that reduces ICP by drawing water out of brain parenchyma.
• Given IV in acute cerebral edema.
• Furosemide and glycerol are less effective in this context.
• Steroids (e.g., prednisolone) are used only for tumors, not for trauma-related ICP.

questions.text: Drug used in emergency management of asthma but not having bronchodilator property:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hydrocortisone
Explanation:
• Hydrocortisone is a systemic corticosteroid.
• It reduces airway inflammation but has no direct bronchodilator effect.
• Salbutamol, ipratropium, and theophylline all cause bronchodilation.

questions.text: Toxicity of lithium occurs it lithium concentration in plasma is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

2 meq/L
Explanation:
• Therapeutic range: 0.6–1.2 mEq/L
• Toxicity begins above 1.5 mEq/L, and severe toxicity can occur at ≥2.0 mEq/L.
• Toxic signs: tremor, ataxia, confusion, GI symptoms, nephrotoxicity.

questions.text: An elderly patient came with features of Parkinsonism like rigidity, hypokinesia etc. Which of the following is not prescribed to this patient:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Rivastigmine
Explanation:
• Rivastigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor used for Alzheimer’s, not Parkinsonism.
• It can worsen Parkinsonian symptoms due to cholinergic excess.
• Ropinirole (dopamine agonist), Carbidopa (with Levodopa), and deep brain stimulation are used in Parkinson’s.

questions.text: Which of the following pair is correct side effect of drugs
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Lamotrigine – Toxic epidermal necrolysis
Explanation:
• Lamotrigine can cause serious skin reactions (SJS/TEN), especially if dose is escalated quickly.
• Topiramate causes weight loss, not gain.
• Vigabatrin → visual field defects.
• Gabapentin usually doesn’t affect vision, but may cause somnolence and dizziness.

questions.text: A patient having pneumonia due to ventilator treatment given ceftriaxone and amikacin. Culture & sensitivity report showing pseudomonas growth, which is having extended spectrum beta lactamase activity. What is the next step of management
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Change the antibiotics to imipenem
Explanation:
• Pseudomonas with ESBL production is resistant to 3rd-gen cephalosporins and aminoglycosides.
• Carbapenems (e.g., imipenem) are drugs of choice for serious ESBL-producing organisms.
• Ceftriaxone is ineffective. Ceftazidime is better for pseudomonas but not ESBL.

questions.text: Which of these drugs is a potent enzyme inhibitor in the liver?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cimetidine
Explanation:
• Cimetidine inhibits CYP450 enzymes → causes drug interactions.
• Can increase levels of warfarin, phenytoin, theophylline, etc.
• Famotidine, nizatidine, and ranitidine have minimal/no CYP inhibition.

questions.text: Which of the following drug is used for reversal of cerebral vasosparin and infarct following subarachnoid hemorrhage
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Nimodipine
Explanation:
• Nimodipine is a calcium channel blocker with cerebral vasoselectivity.
• Prevents and treats vasospasm after SAH (especially in aneurysmal bleed).
• Other CCBs (like verapamil, diltiazem) are not preferred.

questions.text: A girl presented with bell’s palsy on the third day, what is the ideal treatment to this patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Oral steroids and acyclovir
Explanation:
• Early corticosteroids are mainstay of treatment (↓ nerve inflammation).
• Adding acyclovir helps if HSV reactivation is suspected.
• Treatment is most effective when started within 72 hours.

questions.text: One drug addict person presented with ulceration over skin. This patient also having itching and scratch marks over skin. He is having tachycardia, hypertension and mydriasis. Which substance is causing these symptoms:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: A patient having unilateral headache, associated with nausea and vomiting. Which drug can be used to decrease this headache episodes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Propranolol
Explanation:
• This is migraine with nausea/vomiting and photophobia.
• Propranolol is a first-line prophylactic drug for migraine — it reduces the frequency and severity of attacks.
• Sumatriptan is used to abort acute attacks, not for prevention.
• Fluoxetine (SSRI) and Alprazolam (anxiolytic) are not used for migraine prophylaxis.

questions.text: Extrapyramidal symptoms are seen with the use of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

metoclopramide
Explanation:
• Metoclopramide is dopamine D2 receptor antagonist.
• They block D2 receptors in the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ) and the nigrostriatal pathway, causing extrapyramidal side effects (EPS).
• EPS symptoms: acute dystonia, akathisia, Parkinsonism.

choices.text: Partial agonist at mu & antagonist at kappa
Partial agonist at kappa & antagonist at mu
Partial agonist at mu, kappa & delta

questions.text: Mechanism of action of buprenorphine
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Partial agonist at mu & antagonist at kappa
Explanation:
• Buprenorphine is a partial agonist at μ-opioid receptors, which gives analgesia and limited respiratory depression.
• It is also a kappa antagonist — reduces dysphoria.
• Used for opioid dependence and moderate pain.

questions.text: True about Amphotericin – B are all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Protein synthesis inhibitor
Explanation:
• Amphotericin B binds to ergosterol in fungal membranes → forms pores → leakage of ions.
• It is not a protein synthesis inhibitor.
• It is given parenterally, and liposomal forms reduce toxicity.
• It may cause anemia due to nephrotoxicity-induced ↓ erythropoietin.

questions.text: Which of the following antileprotic drug causes skin ichthyosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Clofazimine
Explanation:
• Clofazimine → causes dry, scaly skin (ichthyosis) and skin discoloration (reddish-black).
• Rifampicin: red-orange urine; dapsone: hemolysis in G6PD; minocycline: pigmentation but not ichthyosis

questions.text: Which NSAID undergoes enterohepatic circulation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Piroxicam
Explanation:
• Piroxicam is a long-acting NSAID with enterohepatic recirculation, contributing to its once-daily dosing.
• This recycling also increases its gastric mucosal exposure, raising risk of GI side effects.
• Aspirin, phenylbutazone, indomethacin undergo less significant recirculation.

questions.text: The FDA classified the different category of drugs as A,B,C,D & X in human use. These categories are about
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Fetal risk in pregnancy
Explanation:
• These categories classify drug safety in pregnancy:
o A: Safe
o B: No evidence of risk in humans
o C: Risk not ruled out
o D: Positive evidence of risk
o X: Contraindicated in pregnancy

questions.text: Physostigmine is the antidote for poisoning with antimuscarinic drugs. Another drug of some classneostigmine is not suitable for this because cannot overcome the adverse effect of the anti muscarinic drug in which of the following system
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Central nervous system
Explanation:
• Physostigmine is lipid-soluble → crosses blood-brain barrier → reverses central effects (e.g., delirium).
• Neostigmine is quaternary, doesn’t cross BBB, so ineffective for central symptoms of antimuscarinic poisoning (like from atropine or Dhatura).

questions.text: All are true about Raloxifene except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Decrease venous thromboembolism
Explanation:
• Raloxifene is a SERM (selective estrogen receptor modulator):
o Agonist in bone → ↓ osteoporosis risk
o Antagonist in uterus and breast → ↓ cancer risk
o BUT increases risk of VTE (like estrogen)
• So the statement “decrease VTE” is false.

questions.text: Both decreased bone resorption and increased bone formation caused by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Strontium ranelate
Explanation:
• Strontium ranelate: dual action → stimulates osteoblasts (↑ bone formation) and inhibits osteoclasts (↓ resorption).
• Other options:
o Teriparatide → only ↑ formation
o Calcitonin, Ibandronate → only ↓ resorption

questions.text: Histamine through H1 receptors to cause bronchoconstriction and adrenaline via beta 2 receptors cause bronchodilation to reverse this action. Which type of antagonism is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Physiological
Explanation:
• Physiological antagonism occurs when two drugs act on different receptors to produce opposite effects.
• Example: Histamine (H₁) → bronchoconstriction; Adrenaline (β₂) → bronchodilation.

questions.text: Best treatment of this condition:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Valacyclovir
Explanation:
• Valacyclovir is best for HSV/VZV.
• Ganciclovir is the drug of choice for CMV infections, especially CMV retinitis in immunocompromised patients.
• Valacyclovir is for HSV/VZV.
• Tenofovir → HIV/HBV; Mupirocin → topical antibiotic (not antiviral).

questions.text: A female presented with pain and redness in her great toe. Serum uric acid level was 9.7 mg/dl. Apart from analgesic, one more drug was prescribed to her that decreases the formation of uric acid. Which enzyme is likely to be inhibited by this drug:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: A person from nonendemic area visited India was given prophylaxis for malaria. How long the person should continue the drug after leaving from India:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

4 weeks
Explanation:
• Chloroquine or mefloquine prophylaxis should be continued for 4 weeks after leaving the endemic area.
• Because liver stages may reactivate, and full suppression takes time.

questions.text: The patient having h/o travelling to Assam, developed fever, chills, rigors and altered sensorium. Peripheral smear shows presence of plasmodium falciparum. What is the treatment of choice for this patient:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Artesunate
Explanation:
• Severe falciparum malaria with CNS involvement (cerebral malaria) requires IV artesunate (ACT regimen).
• Chloroquine is ineffective due to resistance.
• Sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine is outdated for monotherapy.

questions.text: A female with 20 weeks pregnancy presents with fever and dysuria. A preliminary diagnosis of cystitis was made. Which of the following drug will be safe to use for this patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Amoxicillin
Explanation:
• Amoxicillin is safe in pregnancy and effective against most urinary pathogens.
• Ciprofloxacin, gentamicin, and cotrimoxazole are contraindicated or risky in pregnancy due to teratogenicity or fetal toxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following is a newer drug approved for MDR-TB patients:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Bedaquiline
Explanation:
• Bedaquiline targets mycobacterial ATP synthase.
• Approved for multidrug-resistant TB.
• Linezolid and levofloxacin are also used, but not new, and Tipranavir is an HIV drug.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is most likely to cause hypoglycemia when used as a monotherapy in the treatment of type 2 diabetes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Glipizide
Explanation:
• Glipizide is a sulfonylurea → increases insulin release → risk of hypoglycemia, especially in elderly or with fasting.
• Metformin, acarbose, and SGLT2 inhibitors (e.g., empagliflozin) have low hypoglycemia risk.

questions.text: Anticoagulant acts via inhibiting factor Xa are all except-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
 Dabigatran
Explanation:
• Dabigatran is a direct thrombin (factor IIa) inhibitor.
• Rivaroxaban, apixaban, and fondaparinux are factor Xa inhibitors.

choices.text: I, II, and III are correct

questions.text:
If a patient on warfarin has an INR greater than 20 and active bleeding that is clinically significant (i.e., hematuria), the pharmacist should
I. Hold the drug therapy
II. Administer vitamin K
III. Administer fresh frozen plasma
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

I, II, and III are correct
Explanation:
• Management includes:
1. Hold warfarin
2. Administer vitamin K (to aid clotting factor production)
3. Give fresh frozen plasma (FFP) to replace clotting factors urgently
• All three steps are standard in major warfarin-induced bleeding.

questions.text: A child brought to emergency with seizures. Airways have been secured and antiepileptic was given. What is the first line drug to control seizures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Diazepam
Explanation:
• In acute convulsions, IV or rectal diazepam is the first-line drug due to its rapid onset.
• It enhances GABA-A activity, providing immediate CNS suppression.
• Other options like phenytoin or valproate are used for maintenance or if seizures persist.

questions.text: The diuretic of choice for rapid relief of congestive symptoms in a patient of congestive heart failure is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Furosemide
Explanation:
• Furosemide is a loop diuretic, very effective for fluid overload in CHF.
• Acts quickly and reduces pulmonary and peripheral edema.
• Thiazides and others are slower and milder.

questions.text: Oral contraceptive pills (OCP’s) fails when used with all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Aspirin
Explanation:
• Rifampicin, phenytoin, and tetracycline are enzyme inducers that increase metabolism of OCPs → contraceptive failure.
• Aspirin does not affect OCP efficacy.

questions.text: Patient underwent surgery and during recovery he was shouting and having hallucinations. Which anaesthetic drug was used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ketamine
Explanation:
• Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic that can cause emergence delirium, hallucinations, and agitation postoperatively.
• It’s an NMDA antagonist, unlike propofol or etomidate.

questions.text: A young male patient is on prolonged oral steroids since more than 10 years. Now having loss of vision in both the eyes. What is the possible reason for this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Posterior subcapsular cataract
Explanation:
• Chronic corticosteroid use can cause posterior subcapsular cataracts, a classic complication.
• Other options like glaucoma or retinal detachment are possible but less likely in this context.

questions.text: Which of the following drug requires therapeutic dose monitoring-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lithium
Explanation:
• Lithium has a narrow therapeutic index → blood levels must be monitored to avoid toxicity (tremors, nephrotoxicity, hypothyroidism).
• Warfarin also requires INR monitoring, but the question asks about drug level monitoring.
• Metformin and propranolol don’t need routine serum monitoring.

choices.text: Binds selectively to SV2A protein of synaptic vesicles

questions.text: Mechanism by which Levetiracetam acts as antiepileptic:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Binds selectively to SV2A protein of synaptic vesicles
Explanation:
• Levetiracetam binds to SV2A, a synaptic vesicle glycoprotein → modulates neurotransmitter release.
• Unique mechanism → few interactions and good safety profile.
• Doesn’t act via NMDA or GABA directly.

questions.text: A school going children not able to focus on his school work and displaying hyperactivity. Which of the following drug improve this patient symptoms
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Methylphenidate
Explanation:
• Methylphenidate is a CNS stimulant used in ADHD.
• Increases dopamine/norepinephrine in synapse → improves attention, behavior.
• Fluoxetine → depression; Theophylline → asthma; Ecstasy → illegal and neurotoxic.

questions.text: Which of the following drug can be used to manage hematemesis caused by infusion of streptokinase in a patient for management of MI
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

. Epsilon amino caproic acid
Explanation:
• Streptokinase is a thrombolytic → dissolves clots → risk of bleeding.
• Epsilon aminocaproic acid is an antifibrinolytic that stabilizes clots.
• Vitamin K is for warfarin overdose; heparin and hirudin are anticoagulants, not antidotes.

questions.text: A patient presents with head injury having headache, vomiting. All the following drugs can be given except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Morphine
Explanation:
• Morphine increases intracranial pressure (ICP) by causing CO₂ retention and vasodilation → contraindicated in raised ICP.
• Ondansetron (antiemetic), diclofenac (analgesic), and pantoprazole (gastric protection) are safe.

questions.text: In a clinical trial, a drug X was evaluated for Hypertension. It was used in healthy human volunteers and drug caused severe gastritis in them. Which phase of clinical trial it was found out?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Phase 1
Explanation:
• Phase 1 trials are conducted in healthy volunteers to assess safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics.
• Discovery of side effects like gastritis occurs here.
• Phase 2 tests efficacy in patients; Phase 3 compares to existing treatments; Phase 4 is post-marketing surveillance.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient was having Hypertension, CHF and microalbuminuria. Which of the following drug will be the best drug for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Telmisartan
Explanation:
• Telmisartan (ARB) is preferred in patients with HTN + heart failure + renal involvement (microalbuminuria).
• It slows diabetic nephropathy and improves cardiovascular outcomes.
• Metoprolol, chlorthalidone, and amlodipine don’t protect kidneys as ARBs do.

questions.text: A young frequent traveler comes to the clinic with complaints of diarrhea and fatigue. The stool specimens show bi nucleate organisms with four flagella as shown in image. Which one of the following is the DOC for the infection caused by the organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Metronidazole
Explanation:
• The description matches Giardia lamblia (binucleate, flagellated protozoa).
• Metronidazole is the treatment of choice.
• Others (quinidine, pentamidine, sulfadoxine) are for malaria or other parasites.

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient is diagnosed with ovarian cancer and was started on cisplatin but complains of severe vomiting after 6 hours of starting cisplatin. Which of the following medications would be most effective to counteract the emesis in this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ondansetron
Explanation:
• Cisplatin-induced nausea is mediated by 5-HT₃ receptors.
• Ondansetron is a 5-HT₃ antagonist → first-line for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV).
• Droperidol, prochlorperazine, and metoclopramide are less effective.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man has myocardial infarction and is being treated for the same in emergency department. Now suddenly he develops ventricular tachycardia. The best drug to treat this arrhythmia is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Lignocaine
Explanation:
• Lidocaine (lignocaine) is a Class 1B antiarrhythmic, effective for ventricular arrhythmias, especially post-MI.
• Acts on ischemic myocardium with minimal effect on normal tissue.
• Digoxin not used in VT; quinidine may worsen VT; metoprolol is used in rate control, not emergency VT.

questions.text: A patient was given IV penicillin and suddenly developed rash on skin, swelling of lips and eyelids, hypotension and difficulty in breathing. DOC in the above condition is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
1:1000 adrenaline IM route
Explanation:
• This is anaphylaxis — a medical emergency.
• Adrenaline 1:1000 IM is the first-line treatment (thigh preferred site).
• IV adrenaline is used only in extreme settings with monitoring.
• Route and dose are critical: IM is safer and faster-acting.

questions.text: A 30 year old male patient was given drug X, as he had pain in facial nerve distribution area while chewing and talking. He now presents with Dilutional Hyponatremia and Hepatotoxicity. Which is the drug X patient is taking
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Carbamazepine
Explanation:
• Carbamazepine → used for trigeminal neuralgia and seizures.
• Side effects:
o SIADH → dilutional hyponatremia
o Hepatotoxicity
• Also causes blood dyscrasias and skin reactions.

questions.text: A pregnant lady was presented to medicine OPD with burning micturition and was diagnosed with UTI. Which of the following antimicrobials is preferred in this patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Amoxicillin + clavulanic acid
Explanation:
• Amoxicillin-clavulanate is safe and effective in pregnancy-related UTIs.
• Avoid:
o Doxycycline (teratogenic)
o Cotrimoxazole (folate antagonist)
o Ciprofloxacin (affects cartilage development)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient is being treated with ABVD chemotherapy for Hodgkin lymphoma. He presents for cycle 4 of a planned 6 cycles with a new-onset complaints of skin problem, consisting of bands of pruritic erythema on the arms, back, scalp, and hands as shown in image. Which drug in the ABVD regimen is the most likely cause of his skin problem
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bleomycin
Explanation:
• Bleomycin is notorious for cutaneous toxicity (e.g., flagellate erythema) and pulmonary fibrosis.
• ABVD regimen = Adriamycin, Bleomycin, Vinblastine, Dacarbazine.
• Skin lesions are classic for bleomycin.

questions.text: Which of the following chemotherapeutic drugs inhibits the polymerization of microtubules but is not associated with causing bone marrow suppression
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Vincristine
Explanation:
• Vincristine → inhibits microtubule formation → arrests cells in metaphase.
• Unlike vinblastine, it causes minimal bone marrow suppression.
• Major toxicity: peripheral neuropathy.
• Others (e.g., 5-FU, cyclophosphamide) suppress marrow.

choices.text: Diazepam is a full agonist, and picrotoxin is a partial agonist
Diazepam is less potent than is picrotoxin

questions.text: In the presence of picrotoxin, diazepam is less efficacious at causing sedation, regardless of the dose. Picrotoxin by itself has no sedative effect even at the highest dose. Which of the following is correct
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Picrotoxin is a noncompetitive antagonist
Explanation:
• Diazepam acts on GABA-A receptors to enhance chloride influx.
• Picrotoxin blocks the chloride channel noncompetitively, reducing diazepam’s effect even at high doses.
• This makes it a noncompetitive antagonist — not reversible by increasing agonist dose.

questions.text: Aminoglycosides have concentration dependent killing property and that property helps in administering the drug by following regimen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Parenterally every 24 hours
Explanation:
• Once-daily dosing of aminoglycosides (like gentamicin) maximizes peak concentration and takes advantage of post-antibiotic effect.
• Reduces nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity.
• Continuous infusion isn't used for these drugs.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male brought to casualty with severe headache. The neurologist attends that patient and orders for investigations. After examination and investigation doctor decides that the pain is due to increased intracranial pressure. Which of the following diuretic is most useful in this situation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Mannitol
Explanation:
• Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic used to rapidly reduce raised intracranial pressure.
• Draws water out of brain tissue → reduces cerebral edema.
• Other diuretics (acetazolamide, furosemide, HCTZ) have slower or different actions.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman had a thrombotic stroke and was given high dose of Alteplase by a newly joined resident in cardiology department. The antidote for its overdose is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Epsilon amino caproic acid
Explanation:
• Alteplase is a fibrinolytic (tPA).
• Epsilon amino caproic acid is an antifibrinolytic, used to counteract bleeding due to fibrinolytics.
• Others:
o Andexanet alfa → antidote for factor Xa inhibitors
o Idarucizumab → for dabigatran
o Protamine sulfate → for heparin

questions.text: A patient came with BP of 190/110mmHg and has blurring of vision and ataxia. What is the best drug for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Fenoldopam
Explanation:
• Fenoldopam is a dopamine D1 agonist used in hypertensive emergencies with renal protection.
• Causes vasodilation → reduces BP.
• Improves renal perfusion, unlike most other vasodilators.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient was having symptoms of excessive thirst and excessive urine production and ADH levels were very low. Which of the following drug will help in above condition of the patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Desmopressin
Explanation:
• The presentation is classic for central diabetes insipidus (DI) → characterized by ADH deficiency.
• Desmopressin (DDAVP) is a synthetic vasopressin analog that acts on V2 receptors → promotes water reabsorption in the kidneys.
• Other options:
o Hydrochlorothiazide: used in nephrogenic DI, not central
o Tolvaptan: V2 antagonist, used in SIADH
o Terlipressin: used for esophageal varices and shock, not DI

questions.text: A 65year old male patient presented with resting tremor, Bradykinesia, rigidity and was diagnosed as a case of Parkinsonism. Which of the following drug used in the treatment of this condition acts by binding to D2 receptor
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Pramipexole
Explanation:
• Pramipexole is a dopamine agonist that directly stimulates D2 receptors in the basal ganglia.
• Used in both early and advanced Parkinson’s disease.
• Other options:
o Amantadine: ↑ dopamine release and has NMDA antagonist properties
o Selegiline: MAO-B inhibitor → prevents dopamine breakdown
o Entacapone: COMT inhibitor → prolongs action of levodopa

questions.text:
A Patient on Secondary prophylaxis of MI. even with dual Antiplatelet therapy he had one more episode of acute coronary syndrome. He was also taking an over the counter drug from many days.
Which of the following may be that drug
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Omeprazole
Explanation:
• Omeprazole inhibits CYP2C19, which is crucial for converting clopidogrel (a prodrug) to its active form.
• This reduces the antiplatelet effect of clopidogrel → increased risk of MI despite therapy.
• Safer alternative: pantoprazole (minimal CYP2C19 inhibition)
• Diclofenac (NSAID) is cardiotoxic long-term but less likely here
• B complex is irrelevant

questions.text: Husband is taking Imipramine for a phobic anxiety disorder, and his wife is taking chlorpromazine for a psychotic disorder. Which of the following adverse effects is likely to occur in both of these individuals
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Orthostatic hypotension
Explanation:
• Both imipramine and chlorpromazine block α₁-adrenergic receptors, leading to orthostatic hypotension.
• It’s a shared side effect of many TCAs and antipsychotics.
• Other options:
o Excessive salivation: uncommon with these drugs (more with clozapine)
o Miosis (pupillary constriction): not typical
o Weight loss: chlorpromazine often causes weight gain

questions.text: Patient came with creatinine 6, otherwise asymptomatic, which drug should be stopped immediately
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Metformin
Explanation:
• Metformin is contraindicated in advanced renal failure due to the risk of lactic acidosis, a potentially fatal complication.
• At creatinine ≥5–6 mg/dL (indicating eGFR <30), metformin must be discontinued immediately.
• Other options:
o Insulin: safe in renal failure (dose adjustment needed)
o Metoprolol: β-blocker, not nephrotoxic
o Linagliptin: DPP-4 inhibitor, safe in renal dysfunction (no dose adjustment required)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man had performance anxiety and migraine headache. Propranolol was used in this patient. What comorbid condition listed below you should very cautious, while using propranolol in this patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Diabetes 
• Explanation: Propranolol, a non-selective beta-blocker, can mask the symptoms of hypoglycemia (e.g., tremors, palpitations) in diabetic patients, making it dangerous. It can also impair glucose recovery from hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman was hospitalized and catheterized with a Foley catheter. She developed a urinary tract infection caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Which of the following is not effective in the treatment of the infection
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Vancomycin 
• Explanation: Vancomycin is primarily effective against Gram-positive bacteria, particularly MRSA. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a Gram-negative bacterium and is inherently resistant to vancomycin. Gentamicin, Cefoperazone, and Cefepime are effective against 
Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

questions.text: A 55-Year-old male was diagnosed with hypertension recently and was started on Hydrochlorthiazide. After 8 months his BP is normal and reads at 124/ 82mm Hg and now he complains of being tired and weak. Which of the following would be responsible for his new complaints?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

• Hypokalemia 
• Explanation: Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic that can cause potassium excretion, leading to hypokalemia. Symptoms of hypokalemia often include fatigue and muscle weakness.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient has long standing DMT2 from last 15 years. He has diabetic gastroparesis and presents with abdominal fullness and heartburn. Which of the following drugs will you avoid in this patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Dulaglutide 
• Explanation: Dulaglutide, a GLP-1 receptor agonist, slows gastric emptying. In patients with diabetic gastroparesis, where gastric emptying is already delayed, using this drug can worsen symptoms like abdominal fullness and heartburn

questions.text: A psychotic patient, 3 days after taking haloperidol, presented with acute dystonia of muscles of neck. Best drug for managing this condition is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Benzhexol 
• Explanation: Acute dystonia is an extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotics like haloperidol. Anticholinergic drugs such as benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl) are the treatment of choice to rapidly relieve these symptoms.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male with a history of a seizure disorder, maintained on phenytoin and phenobarbital, presented to the emergency department for CNS depression. The phenobarbital level was 70 mg/L (15 to 40 mg/L therapeutic range) and the phenytoin level was 15 mg/L (10 to 20 mg/L therapeutic range). He denies any acute ingestion. What therapy can be considered to enhance the elimination of phenobarbital without impacting the phenytoin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Urinary alkalinization 
• Explanation: Phenobarbital is a weak acid, and its elimination can be enhanced by alkalinizing the urine, which promotes its ionization and reduces its reabsorption in the renal tubules. Phenytoin, being less affected by pH changes, would not be significantly impacted.

questions.text: Which one of the following drugs is most suitable in an immunocompromised patient for prophylaxis against infection due to Cryptococcus neoformans
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Fluconazole 
• Explanation: Fluconazole is a commonly used antifungal agent for prophylaxis against Cryptococcus neoformans in immunocompromised patients due to its good oral bioavailability and penetration into the CSF.

questions.text: A Serial actress wanted to get wrinkles removed from her face and was given local injection of Botulinum toxin. The drug acts through
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Inhibition of acetylcholine release 
• Explanation: Botulinum toxin works by inhibiting the release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, leading to muscle paralysis and reduction of wrinkles.

questions.text: Long acting β2 adrenareceptor agonist is (LABA)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Formoterol 
• Explanation: Formoterol is a long-acting beta-2 adrenergic agonist (LABA) commonly used in the management of asthma and COPD for bronchodilation

questions.text: Following are used to Arrest/reversal of disease progression and prolongation of survival in CHF patients except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hydrochlorothiazide 
• Explanation: Enalapril (an ACE inhibitor), Spironolactone (an aldosterone antagonist), and Beta-blockers are all classes of drugs that have been shown to improve survival and reverse disease progression in patients with chronic heart failure. Hydrochlorothiazide (a thiazide diuretic) primarily provides symptomatic relief by reducing fluid overload but does not have a proven mortality benefit in heart failure.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female referred to a dermatologist by her primary care physician because of a painless, inflamed, erupting ulcer that has been on her right hand for two months. This patient works in her vegetable and herb garden daily and states that the lesion began as a small red papule. Despite 10 days of treatment with Cefixime, the papule has continued to enlarge. The dermatologist cultured the ulcer and the results demonstrated the patient has sporotrichosis, an infection caused by Sporothrix-schenckii. What is the most appropriate therapy that should be recommended to treat the infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Itraconazole 
• Explanation: Sporotrichosis, caused by Sporothrix schenckii, is a fungal infection often acquired through contact with contaminated soil or plant matter. Itraconazole is the preferred oral antifungal agent for cutaneous and lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

choices.text: If the patient is taking nitrates avoid Sildenafil
Tadalafil acts by inhibiting PDE V
Vardenafil increases sexual desire in this patient
Alprostadil is an injectable PGE1 used in this patient

questions.text: A 66-year-old man complained of decreased libido and difficulty maintaining an erection. Which of the following is false about drugs used in its treatment
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Vardenafil increases sexual desire in this patient 
• Explanation: Vardenafil (and other PDE5 inhibitors like sildenafil and tadalafil) work by improving erectile function by enhancing the nitric oxide pathway in response to sexual stimulation, but they do not increase sexual desire or libido directly. They facilitate an erection only when sexual desire is already present.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes presents to his physician for a follow up. He complains of repeated episodes of sweating, tremors and palpitations while going for morning walk in empty stomach. Which of these medications is most likely responsible for this patient's complaints?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Glimepiride 
• Explanation: Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea, a class of drugs that stimulate insulin release from pancreatic beta cells. This can lead to hypoglycemia, especially if meals are skipped or exercise is intense, causing symptoms like sweating, tremors, and palpitations.

questions.text: An elderly man was brought to the emergency room after he ingested a large quantity of metoprolol tablets. Which of the following symptoms would you expect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bradycardia 
• Explanation: Metoprolol is a beta-blocker. Overdose typically causes symptoms related to beta-adrenergic blockade, including bradycardia (slow heart rate), hypotension, and potentially bronchospasm or hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A 42 year old male patient came with redness and pain in right great toe. His uric acid level was 10mg/dl. The doctor prescribed a drug for the treatment. Which of the following drug is likely to decrease neutrophil recruitment to inflamed tissue?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Colchicine 
• Explanation: Colchicine is used in acute gout attacks to reduce inflammation. Its mechanism of action involves inhibiting neutrophil migration and activity, thereby decreasing their recruitment to the inflamed joint.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is being treated for atrial arrhythmia. He develops hypothyroidism and pulmonary fibrosis after 2 years. Which one of the following antiarrythmic drug is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Amiodarone 
• Explanation: Amiodarone is a potent antiarrhythmic drug known for its significant and potentially serious long-term side effects, including thyroid dysfunction (both hypo- and hyperthyroidism) and pulmonary fibrosis.

questions.text: A female patient came to casualty complaining of change in colour and numbness of thumb. On asking history she told that she has taken a medicine today for migraine headache. What is the drug responsible and its treatment
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ergotamine and Na Nitroprusside 
• Explanation: Ergotamine is an ergot alkaloid used for migraines. Overdose or sensitivity can cause severe vasoconstriction leading to peripheral ischemia, presenting as numbness and color changes in extremities (ergotism). Sodium nitroprusside is a potent vasodilator used to reverse severe vasoconstriction.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with BPH and an enlarged prostate continues to have urinary symptoms after an adequate doasge of tamsulosin. Dutasteride is added to his therapy to control symptoms. Dutasteride acts by following mechanism in BPH
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

5 alpha reductase inhibitor 
• Explanation: Dutasteride is a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor. It works by blocking the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), which is responsible for prostate growth. By reducing DHT levels, it can shrink the prostate and improve BPH symptoms.

questions.text: A 36 year female patient came with running nose, fever, myalgia and headache from last 7 days. She comes to fever clinic with difficulty in breathing and cough, her SpO2 is 88%, Temp 101 F, PR- 120bpm and normal BP. investigations of patient revealed RTPCR confirmed COVID 19 Infection, chest X ray and CT scan findings also confirmed the same features of infection. He was started on Remdesivir IV and the drug acts by following mechanism
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

RNA dependent RNA polymerase inhibition 
• Explanation: Remdesivir is an antiviral drug approved for the treatment of COVID-19. It acts as an adenosine nucleoside analog, which is incorporated into nascent RNA chains by viral RNA-dependent RNA polymerase, leading to premature termination of RNA transcription.

choices.text: TDM is done with penicillin because of narrow therapeutic index
TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index
TDM is done with both because of dangerous side effects
TDM is done for penicillin as it causes severe anaphylactic

questions.text: Which of the following statement is correct for a patient on a high dose of penicillin and gentamicin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index 
• Explanation: Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic with a narrow therapeutic index, meaning the difference between therapeutic and toxic doses is small. Therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM) is crucial for gentamicin to ensure efficacy and minimize the risk of nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity. Penicillin generally has a wide therapeutic index.

questions.text: A 25-year-old married female was on OCPs for contraception from last 2 years. Two weeks ago she had a positive tuberculosis skin test (PPD test), and a chest radiograph showed evidence of right upper lobe infection. Without asking her drug history, she was started on standard anti mycobacterial therapy. After one and half month she came to the doctor and told that her Urine pregnancy test is positive. Which of the following drug may be the likely reason behind her UPT being positive, even after taking OCPs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Rifampin 
• Explanation: Rifampin is a potent inducer of hepatic microsomal enzymes (CYP450 system). This enzyme induction significantly increases the metabolism of oral contraceptive pills (OCPs), leading to reduced contraceptive efficacy and a higher risk of unintended pregnancy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male was put on medication for hypertension. After 10 days he complains of swelling in both his feet. Which is most likely to cause peripheral edema?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Amlodipine 
• Explanation: Amlodipine is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker widely known to cause peripheral edema (swelling of the ankles and feet) as a common side effect due to its vasodilatory effects.

questions.text: A 48-years-old patient complaints of swelling, redness, and pain in his right leg. The patient is diagnosed with acute DVT and requires treatment with an anticoagulant. Which of the following anticoagulant acts by directly inhibiting Xa?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Rivaroxaban 
• Explanation: Rivaroxaban is a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) that specifically and directly inhibits Factor Xa in the coagulation cascade, thereby preventing clot formation.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child comes to emergency swallowing 10 capsules of iron formulations. Which one of the following drug would be useful in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Deferoxamine 
• Explanation: Deferoxamine is a chelating agent specifically used to treat acute iron poisoning. It binds to iron, forming a complex that can be excreted, thus reducing iron toxicity.

questions.text: A patient was put on topical drug for open angle glaucoma. Now he presents with Macular edema, and the drug given was?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bimatoprost 
• Explanation: Bimatoprost is a prostaglandin analog used to treat open-angle glaucoma. A known side effect of prostaglandin analogs, particularly bimatoprost, is the development or exacerbation of macular edema, especially in patients with predisposing factors.

questions.text: A patient with atrial fibrillation and CHF was started on a drug which acts by vagomimmetic action and by blocking Na K ATPase pump. What is the drug used for the management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Digoxin 
• Explanation: Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside used in atrial fibrillation and CHF. It exerts a positive inotropic effect by inhibiting the Na+/K+-ATPase pump in myocardial cells, and it has vagomimetic (parasympathomimetic) effects that slow AV nodal conduction, beneficial in atrial fibrillation.

choices.text: Entire duration of travel and later 4 weeks after travel

questions.text: A patient visited an endemic area of falciparum malaria and was given prophylaxis for malaria. How many weeks he needs to the take the drug during travel
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Entire duration of travel and later 4 weeks after travel 
• Explanation: For most antimalarial prophylactic regimens, the medication needs to be taken for the entire duration of stay in the endemic area and continued for a specific period (commonly 4 weeks, but can vary by drug) after leaving to cover the parasite's life cycle.

questions.text: After delivery of the baby, the mother had excessive bleeding from vagina in a primary health centre. which of the following drug used in treating the above condition acts as PGF2 analogue
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Carboprost 
• Explanation: Carboprost (15-methyl PGF2α) is a prostaglandin F2α analogue used to treat postpartum hemorrhage. It acts by directly stimulating uterine contractions, which helps to control bleeding.

questions.text: A male patient was diagnosed with sexually transmitted disease and known to be contracted from his sexual partner. He is an alcoholic and he needs to be warned regarding unpleasant symptoms if he consumes alcohol with drug. Which antimicrobial needs a above warning communicated to patient before starting
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: After starting continuous IV Infusion of a drug X, 75% of the drug steady-state concentration is reached after
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

2 half life of drug X 
• Explanation: In pharmacokinetics, approximately 50% of the steady-state concentration is reached after 1 half-life, 75

questions.text: A 28-year-old male complains of 3 days of dysuria and a purulent urethral discharge. You diagnose this to be a case of gonorrhea. Which of the following is appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ceftriaxone IM 
• Explanation: The recommended first-line treatment for uncomplicated gonorrhea is a single intramuscular dose of ceftriaxone, often combined with azithromycin or doxycycline to cover potential coinfection with Chlamydia trachomatis.

questions.text: A patient was on low dose of drug X from last 10years for his allergic condition prescribed by a quack. He comes with blurring of vision and examination of eye was as shown in image. The drug which is responsible for above problem seen in image is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Prednisolone 
• Explanation: The image likely depicts a cataract (clouding of the lens of the eye). Long-term use of corticosteroids like prednisolone is a well-known cause of posterior subcapsular cataracts.

choices.text: Continue once-daily administration of isosorbide mononitrate but advise the patient to take this medication in the night
Advise continuation of isosorbide mononitrate twice daily for full 24-hour coverage of anginal symptoms
Switch to isosorbide dinitrate, as this has a longer duration of action than the mononitrate
Switch to nitroglycerin patch for consistent drug delivery and advise him to wear the patch around the clock

questions.text: Mr. S was having stable angina and was put on isosorbide mononitrate and his symptoms were well controlled. He comes to clinic now and tells that his angina symptoms are coming more in early morning, so he himself decided to take it morning and night after food. What is the best advice given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Continue once-daily administration of isosorbide mononitrate but advise the patient to take this medication in the night 
• Explanation: Nitrates, including isosorbide mononitrate, require a nitrate-free interval (typically 10-14 hours) to prevent the development of tolerance. Taking it twice daily (morning and night) without an adequate interval can lead to tolerance and reduced efficacy, especially for early morning angina. Taking it once daily at night provides coverage during the vulnerable early morning hours while allowing for a nitrate-free period during the day.

choices.text: Ciprofloxacin will decrease the anticoagulant effect of warfarin
Ciprofloxacin will increase the anticoagulant effect of warfarin

questions.text: A 54-year-old female is on warfarin therapy for prevention of deep venous thrombosis. She now develops enteric fever and put on ciprofloxacin by the physician. After 2 days she comes with bleeding episodes. The reason is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ciprofloxacin will increase the anticoagulant effect of warfarin 
• Explanation: Ciprofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic that can inhibit the metabolism of warfarin (a vitamin K antagonist) by interfering with CYP450 enzymes in the liver. This leads to increased warfarin levels and an enhanced anticoagulant effect, thus increasing the risk of bleeding.

questions.text: A 35-Year-old female presented with burning micturition and symptoms of UTI. Which fluroquinolones is least likely to be effective?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Moxifloxacin 
• Explanation: Moxifloxacin has excellent activity against respiratory pathogens and is generally not recommended for urinary tract infections (UTIs) because its urinary concentrations are lower compared to other fluoroquinolones like ciprofloxacin and levofloxacin. It's metabolized more extensively by the liver, leading to less active drug being excreted in the urine.

questions.text: An alcoholic with liver disease comes to OPD with symptoms of alcohol withdrawal. The physician planned to start on a long-term benzodiazepines therapy for this. Which of the following is not suitable in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Alprazolam 
• Explanation: In patients with liver disease, benzodiazepines that undergo extensive hepatic metabolism (like alprazolam) should be avoided or used with extreme caution due to impaired clearance and increased risk of accumulation and toxicity. Lorazepam, temazepam, and oxazepam (LOT drugs) are preferred in liver disease as they are metabolized by glucuronidation, which is less affected by liver dysfunction.

questions.text: A patient was put on morphine for cancer pain due to carcinoma of pancreas. His pain got relieved and the patient took around 6 doses of morphine again to get rid of pain. He came to emergency room with pinpoint pupil and respiratory depression. Best drug to reverse this is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Naloxone 
• Explanation: Naloxone is a pure opioid antagonist that rapidly reverses the effects of opioid overdose, including respiratory depression and pinpoint pupils, by competitively binding to opioid receptors.

questions.text: A 45year old female complains of frequent episodes of one side headache from last 3 years.
