Before headache she has nausea, blurring of vision and lethargy and prefers to stay in quiet dark room. Every month the episodes are increasing. Which drug is helpful in controlling these episodes
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Erenumab 
• Explanation: The symptoms describe classic migraine with aura. Erenumab is a calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptor antagonist, a newer class of drugs specifically approved for the prevention of migraine. Sumatriptan and ergotamine are used for acute attacks, and Ubrogepant is also for acute treatment, not prevention.

choices.text: Nitroprusside (50-year-old man with BP of 140/95 mm Hg)
Propranolol (40-year-old patient with peripheral vascular disease)

questions.text: Which one of the following is the most appropriate drug to use for the patient described in the following scenario
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Captopril (60-year-old woman with diabetic nephropathy) 
• Explanation: ACE inhibitors like Captopril are renoprotective and are the preferred antihypertensive agents in patients with diabetic nephropathy as they slow the progression of kidney disease.

choices.text: Should not be used as it is irrational
Can be used as both have a different mechanism of action
Should not be used due to addiction
Can be used to treat cough effectively

questions.text: If codeine is coming to the market in combination with dextromethorphan as an antitussive. This combination
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Should not be used as it is irrational 
• Explanation: This combination is generally considered irrational because both codeine and dextromethorphan are antitussives, and combining them does not offer additional therapeutic benefit and may increase the risk of side effects.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is diagnosed with HIV. His CD4 + count is 300 cells /mm 3 and his viral load is high. Which of the following will be helpful as prophylactic in preventing pneumonia due to Pneumocystis jiroveci in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cotrimoxazole 
• Explanation: Cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) is the drug of choice for prophylaxis against Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (PJP), formerly called PCP, in HIV-infected individuals, especially when the CD4 count falls below a certain threshold.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male with a childhood history of asthma complained of cough, dyspnea, and wheezing after cleaning the dirt room. His symptoms became so severe and he came to the emergency room. Physical examination revealed diaphoresis, dyspnea, tachycardia, and tachypnea. His respiratory rate was 42 breaths per minute, pulse rate 110bpm, and blood pressure 132/65 mm Hg. Which of the following drugs addition in this situation, increases Beta 2 receptor responsiveness and reduces allergic manifestations
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Intravenous hydrocortisone 
• Explanation: In acute severe asthma exacerbations, corticosteroids like intravenous hydrocortisone are essential. They reduce airway inflammation, decrease hyperresponsiveness, and increase the responsiveness of beta-2 adrenergic receptors to bronchodilators like salbutamol.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient was admitted the hospital with features of muscle pain, fatigue and dark colored urine after a general physician started him with a medication for his sore throat. He was taking Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia and atenolol for hypertension. On lab investigations showed urine dipstick positive for blood but no RBCs in urine microscopy. His serum creatine kinase enzyme is raised. What medication was added by general physician?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Erythromycin 
• Explanation: The patient is on atorvastatin, a statin. Erythromycin, a macrolide antibiotic, is a strong inhibitor of CYP3A4, the enzyme responsible for atorvastatin metabolism. Co-administration can significantly increase atorvastatin levels, leading to increased risk of myopathy and rhabdomyolysis (muscle pain, fatigue, dark urine due to myoglobinuria, and elevated CK).

questions.text: A patient came to emergency ward with low BP and features of pulmonary edema. His ejection fraction of the heart was reduced. Diuretic which is contraindicated in this condition is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Mannitol 
• Explanation: Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that expands intravascular volume. In a patient with low blood pressure, reduced ejection fraction, and pulmonary edema, increasing intravascular volume further could worsen the heart failure and pulmonary edema. Loop diuretics like furosemide are preferred in such conditions.

questions.text: A Patient on antipsychotic therapy for 1 month, develops a feeling of restlessness, frequent repetitive stereotyped movements and an inability to sit still for more than a short period of time. which of the following drug is responsible for this
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

• Haloperidol 
Explanation: The symptoms described (restlessness, repetitive movements, inability to sit still) are characteristic of akathisia, an extrapyramidal side effect commonly associated with typical (first-generation) antipsychotics like haloperidol

questions.text: A 60 year old male patient comes to OPD with lipodystrophy. On taking drug history, he told that he is taking drugs for his HIV infection and drugs are zidovudine, lamivudine and lopinavir/Ritonavir. Which of the following drug is used in the treatment of his lipodystrophy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Tesamorelin 
• Explanation: Tesamorelin is a growth hormone-releasing factor analog approved specifically for the treatment of HIV-associated lipodystrophy, particularly to reduce excess abdominal fat in patients on antiretroviral therapy.

questions.text: A 66 year old hospitalized patient acquired microbial infection while staying in hospital. He is hypertensive and also has a creatinine clearance of 25 mL/ min. Which of the following antimicrobials drugs is least likely to require a dosage adjustment in this patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ceftriaxone 
• Explanation: Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin that is primarily eliminated by hepatic (biliary) excretion, with only a small portion renally excreted. Therefore, it generally requires minimal or no dosage adjustment in patients with significant renal impairment. Gentamicin, Imipenem-cilastatin, and Vancomycin are primarily renally excreted and would require dosage adjustments in this patient with a creatinine clearance of 25 mL/min.

choices.text: Are easily filtered at the glomerulus
Can undergo competition with other drugs for albumin binding sites

questions.text: Drugs that are highly bound to albumin are
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Can undergo competition with other drugs for albumin binding sites 
• Explanation: Drugs that are highly bound to albumin compete for the same binding sites. If another drug with high albumin affinity is introduced, it can displace the first drug, increasing its free (pharmacologically active) concentration and potentially leading to toxicity. Highly protein-bound drugs generally do not easily cross the BBB, are not easily filtered at the glomerulus, and typically have a smaller volume of distribution (Vd).

choices.text: Plasma levels are increased by a high-Na diet
Adverse effects include acne, polydipsia, and polyuria
Spina bifida is major concern in fetal development
It causes symptoms of mild hyperthyroidism in up to 25% of patients

questions.text: Which one of the following statements about lithium is true
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Adverse effects include acne, polydipsia, and polyuria 
• Explanation: Common adverse effects of lithium include dermatological issues like acne, as well as polyuria (increased urination) and polydipsia (increased thirst) due to its effects on renal concentrating ability (nephrogenic diabetes insipidus). Plasma levels are decreased by a high-Na diet (as sodium and lithium compete for renal reabsorption), and lithium causes hypothyroidism, not hyperthyroidism. Spina bifida is a concern with valproate, not primarily lithium.

questions.text: At a high altitude of 3000 m, a person complains of breathlessness & headache. Which of the following can be used for management of this person:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Acetazolamide 
• Explanation: Acetazolamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, is commonly used for the prevention and treatment of acute mountain sickness. It induces metabolic acidosis, which stimulates respiration and improves acclimatization to high altitudes.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient was knocked by a bull and he sustained injuries at abdominal site. The injury resulted in spillage of intestinal contents and he is brought to the emergency room. Which antibiotic would effectively treat an infection due to Bacteroides fragilis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Clindamycin 
• Explanation: Bacteroides fragilis is a common anaerobic bacterium found in the gut. Clindamycin has good activity against Bacteroides fragilis and is often used for intra-abdominal infections, though resistance can occur. Metronidazole is also highly effective. Aztreonam and gentamicin are primarily for Gram-negative aerobes, and azithromycin has limited anaerobic activity.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman is being treated with raloxifene for osteoporosis. There is an increased risk of her developing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Deep Vein thrombosis 
• Explanation: Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used for osteoporosis. Like estrogen, it carries an increased risk of venous thromboembolism, including deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE). It does not increase the risk of uterine cancer and can actually reduce the risk of invasive breast cancer.

questions.text: A patient 58year old had laryngeal cancer and undergone neck irradiation. After that she had decreased salivary secretion and dry mouth. This of the following drug is not useful in the above condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Atropine 
• Explanation: Atropine is an anticholinergic drug that reduces salivary secretions, therefore it would worsen dry mouth and is not useful. Cevimeline and Pilocarpine are muscarinic agonists that increase salivary flow and are useful for xerostomia (dry mouth). Anticholinesterase drugs indirectly increase acetylcholine, which could increase salivary secretions.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male Patient presented with chest pain and was given nitroglycerine sublingual and pain got relieved. The drug acts by following mechanism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

• Releasing NO 
• Explanation: Nitroglycerin is metabolized to nitric oxide (NO), which then activates guanylyl cyclase, leading to increased cGMP and relaxation of vascular smooth muscle, especially in veins (venodilation) and coronary arteries. This reduces preload and improves blood flow to the myocardium, relieving angina.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient has history of angina and heart rate of 94bpm and also has tense personality. His BP now is 154/94mm of Hg. the preferred drug in the treatment of hypertension in this patient is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Metoprolol 
• Explanation: Metoprolol, a beta-blocker, is an excellent choice in this patient. It not only treats hypertension but also helps manage angina by reducing myocardial oxygen demand and can alleviate symptoms associated with a "tense personality" (e.g., tachycardia, anxiety-related symptoms).

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with Rheumatoid arthritis was on medications. After 2 years, he developed Megaloblastic anemia and elevated liver enzymes. Which drug is most likely to cause this
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Methotrexate 
• Explanation: Methotrexate is a folate antagonist commonly used in rheumatoid arthritis. Its side effects include bone marrow suppression (leading to megaloblastic anemia, which can be mitigated with folic acid supplementation) and hepatotoxicity (elevated liver enzymes).

questions.text: Patient presenter with fever, increased urinary frequency and urgency, and mental status changes. He has a penicillin allergy of anaphylaxis. Which of the following β-lactams is the most appropriate choice for gram-negative coverage of this patient’s urinary tract infection
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Aztreonam 
• Explanation: Aztreonam is a monobactam antibiotic that has a distinct beta-lactam ring structure, making it generally safe for use in patients with severe (anaphylactic) penicillin allergies. It provides good gram-negative coverage, including for UTIs. Other beta-lactams (cephalosporins like cefepime/ceftaroline, and carbapenems like ertapenem) have a higher risk of cross-reactivity with penicillin.

questions.text: A 48 year old truck driver complains of seasonal allergies. doctor prescribes one of the following drug for his allergy and after few days his ECG shows QT prolongation. Which one of the following drug was prescribed
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Terfenadine 
• Explanation: Terfenadine was an older, non-sedating H1 antihistamine that was withdrawn from the market due to its risk of causing QT prolongation and potentially fatal arrhythmias (Torsades de Pointes), especially when taken with CYP3A4 inhibitors. The other listed antihistamines (cyclizine, doxylamine, hydroxyzine) are older, sedating antihistamines not primarily associated with QT prolongation.

questions.text: Which one of the following drugs is most likely to block K+ channels in the heart responsible for cardiac repolarization, and also blocks calcium channels in the AV node
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Amiodarone 
• Explanation: Amiodarone is a Class III antiarrhythmic drug that primarily blocks potassium channels, prolonging repolarization and the refractory period. However, it also has effects on sodium and calcium channels, as well as alpha and beta adrenergic receptors, contributing to its broad antiarrhythmic profile. Its calcium channel blocking activity in the AV node can contribute to rate control.

questions.text: A 28year old female has been diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder(GAD). On evaluation, patient revealed history of drug dependence to Phenobarbitone and a variety of other drugs. Along with counseling, she was prescribed a drug helpful in GAD and that has the advantage of no abuse liability. The drug prescribed is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Buspirone 
• Explanation: Buspirone is an anxiolytic that is effective for generalized anxiety disorder (GAD). Unlike benzodiazepines, it has a different mechanism of action (partial agonist at 5-HT1A receptors) and lacks sedative, hypnotic, anticonvulsant, or muscle relaxant properties. Crucially, it has no abuse potential and does not cause physical dependence, making it suitable for patients with a history of substance abuse.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man complains of fever, headache, confusion, aversion to light, and neck rigidity. He was diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. Which of the following is best drug in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ceftriaxone 
• Explanation: Ceftriaxone, a third-generation cephalosporin, is a first-line antibiotic for bacterial meningitis, including meningococcal meningitis, due to its excellent penetration into the cerebrospinal fluid and broad-spectrum activity against common causative pathogens.

questions.text: Mr. Swamy aged 65 has Heart failure and on medication like telmisartan 20mg and metoprolol. He comes to the OPD with complaints of shortness of breath, increased pitting ankle edema, and a 1.5kg weight gain over the last 3 days. He is stable and has no chest pain. Which of the following is the best treatment advice to the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Start furosemide 
• Explanation: The patient is showing signs of fluid overload (shortness of breath, edema, weight gain), indicating decompensated heart failure despite being on an ARB (telmisartan) and a beta-blocker (metoprolol). A loop diuretic like furosemide is the most appropriate immediate intervention to reduce fluid volume and alleviate symptoms.

questions.text: A 40-year male patient was on chemotherapy for non-Hodgkin lymphoma. His total leucocytes count is now 2000cells/mm3. Which of the following drug is effective in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Filgrastim 
• Explanation: Filgrastim is a granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) that stimulates the production and release of neutrophils from the bone marrow. It is used to prevent or treat neutropenia (low leukocyte count, specifically neutrophils) caused by chemotherapy, thus reducing the risk of infection.

questions.text: The drug to be taken only on prescription by registered medical practitioner comes under which schedule?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: A 25 year old female after love failure became depressed and took 10 Tablets of diazepam. She was brought to emergency room after 1 hour. She was drowsy, lethargic and confused. Which of the following drug is best used in this condition
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Flumazenil 
• Explanation: Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine receptor antagonist that can rapidly reverse the sedative and central nervous system depressant effects of benzodiazepine overdose, such as seen with diazepam.

questions.text: A person was under depression and was put on Fluoxetine therapy. Which of the following is likely to be caused by Fluoxetine therapy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Sexual dysfunction 
• Explanation: Sexual dysfunction (e.g., decreased libido, anorgasmia, erectile dysfunction) is a very common and bothersome side effect associated with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) like fluoxetine.

questions.text: A 23 -year-old male Mr. X was brought to emergency room by his father. When the father was asked about history, father told that Mr. X ate some seeds from a plant and started behaving crazy. On examination he was confused, his skin was hot and dry. His pupils were dilated and unresponsive to light. Blood pressure was 180/105 mm Hg, pulse 150/min, and rectal temp 40 C (104 F). The treatment of choice for above poisoning is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Physostigmine 
• Explanation: The symptoms (confusion, hot and dry skin, dilated pupils, tachycardia, hypertension, hyperthermia) are classic signs of anticholinergic poisoning (e.g., from Jimsonweed seeds, which contain atropine-like alkaloids). Physostigmine is a reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that crosses the blood-brain barrier and can reverse both central and peripheral anticholinergic effects.

choices.text: Active efflux of the drug from the bacteria

questions.text: A nurse was given Mupirocin to eradicate MRSA carrier state. What is the most likely mechanism of resistance for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus to antistaphylococcal penicillins
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Structural modifications of PBPs 
• Explanation: Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) derives its resistance to methicillin and other beta-lactam antibiotics primarily through the acquisition of the mecA gene. This gene encodes for a modified penicillin-binding protein (PBP2a or PBP2') that has a low affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics, rendering them ineffective.

choices.text: The patient is probably tolerant to pentazocine
The patient is a morphine addict
Pentazocine was used at the wrong dose
Pentazocine doesn’t cross the blood-brain barrier

questions.text: A patient comes to the ER with a painful stab wound. The ER resident administers pentazocine for the pain. Soon after administration the patient experiences sweating, restlessness, and an increase in pain sensations. What is the most likely explanation for his symptoms
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The patient is a morphine addict 
• Explanation: Pentazocine is an opioid agonist-antagonist. In patients who are physically dependent on full opioid agonists (like morphine), administering a mixed agonist-antagonist can precipitate opioid withdrawal symptoms (e.g., sweating, restlessness, increased pain) because of its antagonist activity at the mu-opioid receptor.

choices.text: Co2 retention due to opioid use

questions.text: A patient with pelvic fracture and trauma was given morphine for pain. Following which he develops respiratory difficulty. What could be the cause
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Co2 retention due to opioid use 
• Explanation: Morphine, an opioid analgesic, is a well-known respiratory depressant. It reduces the sensitivity of the respiratory center in the brainstem to carbon dioxide, leading to hypoventilation and CO2 retention, which manifests as respiratory difficulty.

choices.text: A combination of an estrogen and progestin

questions.text: A 24-year-old married woman has failed to become pregnant after 2 years of unprotected intercourse. Which of the following would be effective in treating infertility due to anovulatory cycles?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Clomiphene 
• Explanation: Clomiphene citrate is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that acts as an anti-estrogen in the hypothalamus, thereby blocking negative feedback and increasing the pulsatile release of GnRH. This leads to increased FSH and LH secretion, stimulating follicular development and ovulation, making it effective for anovulatory infertility.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes is diagnosed with heart failure. Which of the following medications would be best choice for controlling her diabetes and to decrease mortality in Heart failure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Empagliflozin 
• Explanation: Empagliflozin is a SGLT2 inhibitor that not only improves glycemic control in type 2 diabetes but has also shown significant benefits in reducing cardiovascular mortality and hospitalizations for heart failure, making it a preferred choice for diabetic patients with established heart failure.

questions.text: A 32 year old patient had anaphylactic shock and was give Inj. Adrenaline 1: 1000 by IM route. The actions of histamine are antagonized by adrenaline. This type of antagonism is called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Physiological antagonism 
• Explanation: Physiological antagonism occurs when two drugs act on different receptors or pathways but produce opposing physiological effects. Adrenaline acts on adrenergic receptors to produce vasoconstriction and bronchodilation, counteracting the vasodilation and bronchoconstriction caused by histamine release in anaphylaxis, even though they don't act on the same receptors.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male patient has a history of chronic gout. His BP is now 156/90mmHg and the physician decided to start him on an ARB for managing his HTN. which one of them is best to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Losartan 
• Explanation: Losartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) that, unlike other ARBs, has a mild uricosuric effect, meaning it can increase uric acid excretion. This makes it a particularly beneficial choice for hypertensive patients who also have hyperuricemia or gout.

questions.text: A 46 year-old man with a history of recurrent generalized tonic-clonic seizures visits his psychiatrist to refill his prescriptions. He complains of weight gain, loss of hair and his lab investigation revealed increased liver enzymes and ammonia levels. His doctor thinks that these new symptoms are related to one of his medications. Which of these drugs is most likely responsible for these new symptoms
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Valproate 
• Explanation: Valproate (valproic acid) is an anticonvulsant commonly used for generalized tonic-clonic seizures. Its well-known side effects include weight gain, hair loss (alopecia), and hepatotoxicity (elevated liver enzymes, hyperammonemia, and rarely hepatic failure).

questions.text: 35 year old hyperthyroid female patient was started on anti thyroid drugs. The drug acts by inhibition of release of thyroid hormone. Which drug is it
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sodium iodide 
• Explanation: High doses of iodide (e.g., as sodium iodide) can acutely inhibit the release of preformed thyroid hormones from the thyroid gland, an effect known as the Wolff-Chaikoff effect, making it useful in thyroid storm or before surgery. Propylthiouracil inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis.

choices.text: Induces P450 enzymes to enhance elimination
Supplies sulfhydryl groups to detoxify a reactive metabolite

questions.text: A 33 year old patient came to casualty after consuming 8 tablets of paracetmol 650mg prescribed for COVID 19 fever. He was depressed about the COVID 19 infection. He was given N acetyl cysteine as an antidote and the benefit from it is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Supplies sulfhydryl groups to detoxify a reactive metabolite 
• Explanation: Paracetamol (acetaminophen) overdose leads to the accumulation of a toxic metabolite, NAPQI. N-acetylcysteine (NAC) works by replenishing glutathione stores, which provides sulfhydryl groups to detoxify NAPQI, and also by directly binding to NAPQI. This prevents NAPQI from causing hepatocellular damage.

questions.text: Levodopa and carbidopa combination doesn't reduce which of the following side effect
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Psychosis 
• Explanation: The combination of levodopa and carbidopa (Sinemet) significantly reduces peripheral side effects of levodopa like severe vomiting and arrhythmias by inhibiting its peripheral metabolism. However, central nervous system side effects such as psychosis (hallucinations, delusions) are due to increased dopamine activity in the brain and are often not reduced, and can even be exacerbated, by levodopa. Hypertension is not a common side effect of this combination.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with Rheumatoid arthritis was on medications. After 2 years, he developed blurring of vision and was found to have corneal opacity. Which drug is most likely to cause this
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hydroxychloroquine 
• Explanation: Hydroxychloroquine is an antimalarial drug used in rheumatoid arthritis. Although rare, long-term use can cause ocular toxicity, including corneal deposits (corneal opacity, which is usually reversible) and, more seriously, retinal toxicity (maculopathy, which can lead to irreversible vision loss).

questions.text:
A 58 year old male patient had BMI of 35. His physician started him on a drug for managing obesity.
The drug lowers glucose and given via Parentral route. Identify the drug
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Liraglutide 
• Explanation: Liraglutide is a GLP-1 receptor agonist that is administered parenterally (subcutaneously). It is approved for both type 2 diabetes management and weight management (at higher doses for obesity) and works by slowing gastric emptying, increasing satiety, and promoting glucose-dependent insulin release.
